media:group.media:title: Armenia celebrates Independence Day
media:group.media:description:
๐ Armenia celebrated its 33rd Independence Day with Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan pledging to continue fostering the countryโs security and democracy. ๐ Bagrat Galstanyan held a rally with his supporters, gathering a crowd of people for the first time since June, and announcing a new protest scheduled for October 2. ๐ Canadian Foreign Minister Melanie Joly issued a statement, condemning Azerbaijanโs ethnic cleansing of Nagorno-Karabakhโs Armenians last September and calling for continued negotiations. ๐ THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS: youtu.be/XDzelR6WfI4?si=kT4ZugMZ-7szECAd ๐ Gurumiran performs live at CivilNet: youtu.be/pjBp3yisWoY?si=Q8vLGwOA1UwCRVuN

entry.title: The Collapse of the Soviet Union: Roundtable Discussion

media:group.media:title: The Collapse of the Soviet Union: Roundtable Discussion
media:group.media:description:
Anatol Lieven, Sheila Fitzpatrick, Svetlana Savranskaya, and Thomas Graham held a roundtable discussion titled โCollapse of the Soviet Unionโ at a symposium on Russia organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The discussion took place on July 7, 2024, in Tbilisi and was moderated by distinguished historian Ronald Grigor Suny.
Anatol Lieven is an author, journalist, and policy analyst. He is a visiting professor at King's College London and a senior fellow at the Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft.
Sheila Fitzpatrick is an Australian historian renowned for her expertise on Soviet and modern Russian history, particularly during Joseph Stalinโs rule.
Svetlana Savranskaya is the director of Russia programs at the National Security Archives in the United States.
Thomas Graham was special assistant to the U.S. president on Russia from 2004 to 2007. He is a distinguished fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations
This yearโs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20.

ีีธึีทีซีซีธึีด 1992-ีซีถ ีฐีซีดีถีกีคึีพีกีฎ ยซีีกึีกีถีคีกยป ีฅึีฃีนีกีญีธึีดีขีจ 32 ีฟีกึีซ ีกีถึ ีฃีธึีฎีธึีถีฅีธึีฉีตีธึีถีจ ีทีกึีธึีถีกีฏีธึีด ีง ิตึึีกีถีธึีดี ีฏีซีฝีกีฟ ีฏีกีฆีดีธีพึ ิตึีฃีนีกีญีดีขีซ ีฐีซีดีถีกีคีซึ, ีญีดีขีกีพีกึ, ีฌีซีขีกีถีกีถีกีฐีกีต ีฅึีกีชีซีทีฟ ิถีกึีกึ ีีฅีทีซีทีตีกีถีจ ีีซีพีซีฌีีฅีฉีซ ีฐีฅีฟ ีฆึีธึีตึีธึีด ีบีกีฟีดีธึีด ีง, ีฉีฅ ีซีถีนีบีฅีฝ ีฅีถ ีีธึีทีซีถ ีฏีธึึีถีฅีฌีธึึ ีฐีฅีฟีธ ีฅึีฅีญีกีถีฅึีซ ีญีถีคึีกีถึีธีพ ีธึ ีฐีธึีคีธึีธีพ ีถีกีญ ีีฟีฅึีกีถีกีฏีฅึีฟีธึีด, ีกีบีก, ิฑึึีกีญีถ ีกีดีขีธีฒีปีธึีฉีตีกีดีข ีฏีธึึีถีฅีฌีธึึ ีฐีฅีฟีธ, ิตึึีกีถีธึีด ีฐีกีดีกีญีดีขีพีฅีฌ, ีธึีชีฅึีจ ีฐีกีพีกึีฅีฌ, ึึีฟีถีกีปีกีถ ีกีทีญีกีฟีฅีฌ, ึีธึีฑีฅึ ีธึ ีฐีกีดีฅึีฃีถีฅึ ีฏีกีฆีดีกีฏีฅึีบีฅีฌี ีธึีบีฅีฝีฆีซ ยซิฑึึีกีญีซ ีฑีกีตีถีจยป ีฅึีขีฅึ ีนีดีกึีซึ

Gurumiran ีญีธึีดีขีจ ีฝีฟีฅีฒีฎีฅีฌ ีง ีฌีซีขีกีถีกีถีกีฐีกีต ีีซึีกีถ ิณีธึึีธึีถีตีกีถีจึ ีีซึีกีถีจ ิฒีฅีตึีธึีฉีซึ ีง, 2020-ีซีถ ีีธีพีซีคีซ, ีกีบีก ิฒีฅีตึีธึีฉีธึีด ีฟีฅีฒีซ ีธึีถีฅึีกีฎ ีบีกีตีฉีตีธึีถีซึ ีฐีฅีฟีธ ีฟีฅีฒีกึีธีญีพีฅีฌ ึ ีฐีกีฝีฟีกีฟีพีฅีฌ ีง ีีกีตีกีฝีฟีกีถีธึีดึ ีีซึีกีถีซ ีฝีฟีฅีฒีฎีกีฃีธึีฎีธึีฉีตีธึีถีถีฅึีจ ีธีฃีฅีทีถีนีพีกีฎ ีฅีถ ีดีทีกีฏีธึีฉีกีตีซีถ ีขีกีฆีดีกีฆีกีถ ีกีฆีคีฅึีธึีฉีตีธึีถีถีฅึีซึึ Gurumiran ีญีดีขีซ ีกีผีกีปีซีถ ีกีฌีขีธีดีจ ีฌีธึีตีฝ ีง ีฟีฅีฝีฅีฌ 2015-ีซีถึ ีึีกีถึ ีฝีฟีฅีฒีฎีกีฃีธึีฎีธึีด ีฅีถ ีฐีกีตีฅึีฅีถ, ีกีถีฃีฌีฅึีฅีถ, ีกึีกีขีฅึีฅีถ ึ ึึีกีถีฝีฅึีฅีถึ ิฝีดีขีซ Notes from Underground ีกีฌีขีธีดีจ ีฏีฉีธีฒีกึีฏีพีซ 2025-ีซีถึ
CivilNet hosted the Gurumiran band for an exclusive performance to mark Armeniaโs independence day on September 21.
Gurumiran was created by Lebanese Armenian artist and musician Miran Gurunian, who relocated to Yerevan from Beirut after the COVID-19 pandemic and port explosion in 2020. Miran says his creations are inspired by his diverse cultural influences, and since his bandโs debut in 2015, Gurumiran has made music in Armenian, English, Arabic, and French. The band's newest album, โNotes from Underground,โ will be released next year.

entry.title: Senior U.S. diplomat visits Armenia amid deepening relations

media:group.media:title: Senior U.S. diplomat visits Armenia amid deepening relations
